content.webTitle: This week's blog: 'Who's TV's best cat?'

fields.headline: This week's blog
fields.bodyText: This week, for no reason at all other than that I got a spam email from a man called Mr Kitten yesterday, we're doing a list of top 10 television cats. Here's a list of just some of the TV cats that could be described as "top". 1. Top Cat 2. Tom (as in "and Jerry") 3. Cookie - all right, Socks - the Blue Peter cat 4. Snarf from Thundercats 5. Stimpy (as in "Ren and") 6. Snowball - the much-ignored Simpson family cat 7. Azrael - angry, vicious, named after the angel of death, eats Smurfs 8. Custard ("Roobarb and") 9. Cat from Red Dwarf 10. Bagpuss So, what are your favourite television kitties? You can't forget the Corrie cat - it's only in the theme, but it must be the oldest British TV cat. oldornew Ardal O'Hanlon as Thomas Kincade Brannigan in Doctor Who last year: a cat dressed like Biggles, but somehow unmistakably Ardal O'Hanlon. ShatterFace Kipper - the narcoleptic mog in Sooty and Sweep. thewinslowboy Vienna - Rigby's cat in Rising Damp. Like Arthur Daley's 'er indoors, Vienna was never seen but had a distinctive screen presence. zephirine Henry's Cat! Housecat There must be room for Postman Pat's black-and-white cat, Jess. bobshirunkel Fifi from Hector's House! The sexiest of cartoon cats. jfldevaney Sylvester every time - particularly because he's up against the insufferable Tweetie Pie. LondonLouis Willy Fogg's Indian princess. She created the (Indian) cat and (British) lion relationship: not only cross-cultural, but also cross-species love. It broke boundaries, I tell you. SaintSnowy Cheetara [from Thundercats]. She was definitely the most attractive cat on TV for a hell of a long time. MrMydak I can't believe that so many men fancied Cheetara. I mean, she had whiskers, for chrissakes. biba24 Clarence the crossed-eyed lion from Dactari was one hell of a cool dude. Never even tried to eat the humans. cks172 Wot, no Cat Deeley? MacVista Also on this week's arts blog: · Jean Hannah Edelstyn Plenty of writers could knock Amis, Barnes, Ishiguro and McEwan off their perch. So why aren't we reading them? · Jonathan Glancey Could anyone today design something as instantly recognisable and long-lasting as the CND logo? Take part in the debate - go to blogs.theguardian.com/arts
